INDICATOR:: Social condition in exporting countries to EU
UNIT:: %; PPP; rate per 1000 live births; a unitless scale of 0 to 100, with 100 being the optimal value
Description of the indicator/signal/pote: This indicator consists of seven sub-indicators to give an indication of the social condition in countries that trade with the EU related to bioeconomy.
Methodological considerations: NA
Required methodology: The sub-indicators are: - Informal employment: In contexts where social protection coverage is limited, social security benefits are insufficient, and/or where wages and pensions are low, individuals may have to take up informal employment to ensure their livelihood. Statistics on informality are key to assessing the quality of employment in an economy. - Compliance of labour rights: This sub-indicator measures the level of national compliance with fundamental rights at work, specifically freedom of association and collective bargaining by assessing trade union density. - Minimum wage: Minimum wage is the minimum earnings employers can legally pay their staff. The main purpose is to protect workers from unduly low earnings and exploitation. Most countries have implement minimum wage legislation, however some have not and are therefore excluded. - Poverty rate: Monitoring poverty is important on the global development agenda as well as for many countries. Poverty rate is reported for age 15+ years. - Infant mortality rate: Mortality rates among young children is a key output indicator for child health and well-being, as well as for social and economic development. It also reflects the access of children and communities to basic health interventions such as vaccination and adequate nutrition. - Coverage of essential health service: The average coverage of essential services is based on tracer interventions that include reproductive, maternal, newborn and child health, infectious diseases, non-communicable diseases as well as service capacity and access. Here, the universal health coverage (UHC) index is used as indicator. - Gender pay gap: This sub-indicator highlights gender equality related to wages by measuring the relative difference between the average hourly earnings for men and for women.
Headline: NA
Societal Goals: SO3 Reducing dependence on non-renewable unsustainable resources, whether sourced domestically or from abroad

Description of the indicator/signal/pote: Multiple successive uses of woody biomass in different sectors, first as logs and then as industrial by-products or post-consumer recovered resources, is referred as “cascading”. The more often by-products and recycled woody biomass are used in non-energy sectors, the higher the percentage of secondary woody biomass used by material industry on the total uses of woody biomass.
Methodological considerations: Data for the calculations are derived by the Joint Forest Sector Questionnaire, Eurostat, the Joint Wood Energy Enquiry, the National Renewable Energy Action Plan Progress reports of Member States. The factors are consistent with the Wood Resource Balances (WRB) published by JRC (Cazzaniga et al., 2021).
Required methodology: The share of secondary woody biomass for material industry is calculated as the ratio between the secondary woody biomass used by material industry and the total uses of woody biomass. Likewise, the share of secondary woody biomass for energy is obtained by dividing the amount of secondary woody biomass for energy by the total uses of woody biomass.
